displaytitle: Triptych: Madonna and Child, Annunciation, Flagellation/Crucifixion
creditline: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Reder in memory of their only son, Emmanuel Reder, who died in the invasion of Normandy in 1944, and an anonymous gift

titles.title: Triptych: Madonna and Child, Annunciation, Flagellation/Crucifixion

texts.textentryhtml: The painter of the Madonna and Child in the central panel of this altarpiece (perhaps from Pisa) was highly conversant with Byzantine images and icons—traditions of the Greek world. The inclusion of the Flagellation scene alongside the usual Crucifixion and Annunciation suggests that a member of a penitential flagellant confraternity commissioned the work.

Wladimir de Gruneisen, Paris (1868-after 1932); Brussels Art Market, late 1920s/early 1930s [1]; Jacob Reder, New York (from about 1940); 1958 gift to Princeton University Art Museum

[1] Estimate based on a photograph from Jean Malvaux in Brussels. See M. Boskovits, The Origins of Florentine Painting Vol. 1, trans. Robert Erich Wolf (Florence, 1993), p. 432.

Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Reder in memory of their only son, Emmanuel Reder, who died in the invasion of Normandy in 1944, and an anonymous gift (y1958-126)
